{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Marcus Einfeld |image = |image_size = |caption = | office = Judge of the [[Federal Court of Australia]] | term_start = 18 December 1986 | term_end = 16 April 2001 | appointer = [[Ninian Stephen]] | office1 = President of the [[Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission]] | term_start1 = 10 December 1986 | term_end1 = 10 December 1989 | predecessor1 = ''New position'' | successor1 = [[Ronald Wilson]] |birth_name = Marcus Richard Einfeld |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1938|9|22|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]], Australia |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |nationality = Australian |alma_mater = [[University of Sydney]] ([[Bachelor of Laws|LL.B.]]) |relations = [[Syd Einfeld]] (father) }}
'''Marcus Richard Einfeld''' (born 22 September 1938) is a former Australian judge who served on the [[Federal Court of Australia]] and was the inaugural president of the [[Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission]]. In retirement, he served two years in prison after being convicted of [[perjury]] and [[perverting the course of justice]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Einfeld jailed|publisher=[[ninemsn]]|date=20 March 2009|accessdate=20 March 2009|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/national/788779/einfeld-lied-to-avoid-demerit-judge|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090322110935/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/national/788779/einfeld-lied-to-avoid-demerit-judge|archivedate=22 March 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Einfeld studied law at the [[University of Sydney]]. His father [[Syd Einfeld]] was a federal MP. He was [[call to the bar|called to the bar]] in 1962, and appointed [[Queen's Counsel]] (QC) in 1977. From 1972 to 1976, Einfeld was a director of the [[World Jewish Congress]], based in London. After returning to Australia he became one of [[Sydney]]'s most prominent barristers. Einfeld was appointed to the Federal Court in 1986, serving until 2001. In the same year he was made the inaugural president of the [[Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission]], serving until 1989. He was also the inaugural president of the [[Australian Paralympic Committee]] from 1990 to 1992.
In 2006, Einfeld was issued a A$77 [[speeding ticket]] for travelling 10 km/h (6.2 mph) over the limit. He appealed the ticket, claiming that he had not been driving. Journalists subsequently discovered that he had made a number of false statements under oath; the woman he had said was driving had in fact died several years earlier. Einfeld was arrested in 2007, and the following year pleaded guilty to perjury and perverting the course of justice. He was sentenced to three years' imprisonment. As a result of his actions, Einfeld was expelled from the legal profession and stripped of many of the honours he had previously accumulated, including his status as a Queen's Counsel, appointment of the [[Order of Australia]], and his status as a [[National Living Treasure (Australia)|National Living Treasure]].
==Early life== Einfeld was born in Sydney, and was named after his paternal grandfather who had died a year earlier.<ref name=autogenerated12>Fiona Harari (2011). [https://books.google.com/books?id=6dUagyDow7UC&pg=PA4&dq=%22Marcus+Einfeld%22+%22sydney+boys%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiK8oz8wv_ZAhWRmeAKHa6MDEYQ6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=%22Marcus%20Einfeld%22%20%22sydney%20boys%22&f=false ''A Tragedy in Two Acts: Marcus Einfeld and Teresa Brennan''<!-- Bot generated title -->], Victory Books.</ref> He has a sister.<ref name=autogenerated8 /> His parents were the [[Australian Labor Party|Labor Party]] politician [[Syd Einfeld]] and his wife Billie Rose (née Appelboom), who married in June 1934.<ref name=autogenerated8>[https://judaica.library.sydney.edu.au/histories/SydEinfeld.html "Sydney David Einfeld, Politician and Community Leader (1907-1985)" - Julius Stone<!-- Bot generated title -->], Archive of Australian Judaica.</ref> His father served in both [[Parliament of Australia|Federal Parliament]] and the [[Parliament of New South Wales]].<ref name=autogenerated8 /> Einfeld's paternal grandfather was Rev. Marcus Einfeld (1874-1937), who came to Australia in 1909 (becoming the ''[[chazan]]'' and the Second Minister of the [[Great Synagogue (Sydney)|Great Synagogue]]) by way of London, England, to which he had immigrated from [[Jarosław]] in [[Galicia (Eastern Europe)|Galicia]] with his wife Deborah (née Gabel; d. 1957).<ref name=autogenerated3>Raymond Apple (2008). [https://books.google.com/books?id=iRKXMz7-5s0C&pg=PA113&lpg=PA113&dq=%22Marcus+Einfeld%22&source=bl&ots=cKgGpcGNeZ&sig=RiTyRYBeOIHq6VZ_dBD1k64Jjkc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjTwNHNrv_ZAhVKmeAKHcDTC5g4KBDoAQhoMA4#v=onepage&q=%22Marcus%20Einfeld%22&f=false ''The Great Synagogue: A History of Sydney's Big Shule,''<!-- Bot generated title -->] Great Synagogue (Sydney, N.S.W.), UNSW Press.</ref><ref name=autogenerated8 /><ref>Suzanne Duke (1984). [https://books.google.com/books?id=TXkZAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Marcus+Einfeld%22+%22sydney+boys%22+1955&dq=%22Marcus+Einfeld%22+%22sydney+boys%22+1955&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiht8vawf_ZAhWION8KHaWCAocQ6AEIKTAA ''Debrett's Handbook of Australia and New Zealand''<!-- Bot generated title -->], Volume 2, Debrett's Peerage Limited, Debrett's Peerage (Firm).</ref>
Einfeld attended [[Sydney Boys High School]] from 1951 to 1955.<ref name=autogenerated12 /> He then obtained his [[Bachelor of Laws]] degree from the [[University of Sydney]] in 1962.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://alumniarchives.sydney.edu.au/as|title=Marcus Einfeld profile|website=Alumni Sidneienses|publisher=University of Sydney|accessdate=July 3, 2015}}</ref> At some point, Einfeld began claiming that he held doctorates from both "Century University" and "[[Pacific Western University]]"; both are U.S.-based [[diploma mill]]s without any accreditation as law schools. Those qualifications were referred to by Attorney-General [[Lionel Bowen]] when Einfeld was added to the Federal Court in 1987, and were listed in his ''[[Who's Who in Australia]]'' entry until 2007. His updated ''Who's Who'' entry, which was published after he had been arrested and charged with perjury, also corrected his year of birth (previously listed as 1939) and removed a claim that he had once been a director of the multinational firm [[Marks & Spencer]] in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite book|title=A Tragedy In Two Acts: Marcus Einfeld And Teresa Brennan|publisher=Melbourne University Publishing|year=2011|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=21WEiJvmTI4C|author=Fiona Harari|pages=96–97; 155}}</ref>
===Marriages and children=== Einfeld has four children, two from each of two marriages.<ref>Chris Back, "Work in Progress: Marcus Einfeld", ''[[Weekend Australian]]'', 3–4 June 2000</ref> He married his first wife Yetta, a teacher, in 1963 and that had two children before they divorced in 1977.<ref name=autogenerated10>Fiona Harari (2011). [https://books.google.com/books?id=6dUagyDow7UC&pg=PA70&dq=%22Marcus+Einfeld%22+married+sylvia&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiXyofUuv_ZAhXxTN8KHaIRDXEQ6AEIKTAA#v=snippet&q=%22Marcus%20Einfeld%22%20anne%20wife&f=false ''A Tragedy in Two Acts: Marcus Einfeld and Teresa Brennan''<!-- Bot generated title -->], Victory Books.</ref> He married his second wife Anne, an attorney, in 1982 and they had two children before they divorced in 1996.<ref name=autogenerated10 />
==Legal and judicial career==
Einfeld became a [[barrister]] in 1962.<ref name=autogenerated11>Michael Pelly (6 October 2009). [http://www.news.com.au/news/jail-completes-marcus-einfelds-fall/news-story/566a2ab324c9033213064010e4c59817 "Jail completes Marcus Einfeld's fall"<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He was appointed a [[Queen's Counsel]] (QC) in 1977, aged 39.<ref name="qc revoked">{{cite web|title=Einfeld stripped of QC status|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=26 November 2008|accessdate=26 November 2008|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/11/26/2430680.htm}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated6>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/7967982.stm "The little white lie that grew,"<!-- Bot generated title -->] BBC News | Magazine.</ref><ref name=autogenerated10 /> He represented High Court Justice [[Lionel Murphy]] in his legal challenge to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry which had been established to examine whether Murphy had perverted the course of justice; the inquiry was suspended when Murphy became terminally ill.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/118134379|date=29 July 1986|publisher=''[[The Canberra Times]]''|title=Murphy drops legal challenge}}</ref>
Einfeld was appointed to the Federal Court in 1986.<ref name=autogenerated11 /> Einfeld was also an additional Justice of the [[Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory|Australian Capital Territory]]. He retired as a judge in April 2001.<ref name=autogenerated9>[http://www.abc.net.au/4corners/the-dishonouring-of-marcus-einfeld/8953040 "The Dishonouring of Marcus Einfeld" - Four Corners<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Einfeld was the founding president of the [[Australian Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission]]. He was appointed to a seven-year term in December 1986,<ref>[trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/240546548 Commonwealth of Australia Gazette], 10 December 1986</ref> but resigned after three years citing an inability to combine the role with his judicial duties.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/120863928|publisher=''[[The Canberra Times]]''|title=Einfld 'intended to quit in 3 years'|date=2 December 1989}}</ref> In 1987 he led the Commission's enquiry into the living conditions of Aborigines in the border area of [[New South Wales]] and [[Queensland]].<ref name=autogenerated6 /><ref name=autogenerated14>[http://redandrobin.com.au/ICHRS/?page_id=147 "Marcus Einfeld" | ICHRS<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> An [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginal]] elder praised his work with indigenous communities when he was Human Rights Commissioner.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
==Community and social involvement== Einfeld has served as [[Austcare|Austcare's]] "Ambassador for Refugees", and as a [[UNICEF]] "Ambassador for Children".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gg.gov.au/governorgeneral/speech.php?id%3D131 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-07-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091004121241/http://www.gg.gov.au/governorgeneral/speech.php?id=131 |archivedate=4 October 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name=autogenerated7>Justice Marcus Einfeld AO QC. [https://www.safecom.org.au/einfeld.htm "The Great Australian Brain Robbery: the hijacking of the Australian conscience"<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 1997, he was named by the [[National Trust of Australia]] as an [[Australian Living Treasures|Australian Living Treasure]], one of up to 100 living people selected by popular vote for having made outstanding contributions to Australian society.<ref name=autogenerated6 /> In 2002 he was granted the [[United Nations]] Peace Award.<ref name=autogenerated6 /> He has also served as National Vice President of the [[International Commission of Jurists]] (Australian Section).<ref name=autogenerated7 /> In 2002, he was presented a [[United Nations Association of Australia]] Founder's Award for his contribution to justice and [[human rights]].<ref name=autogenerated14 /> He served as Chairman of Legal Resources International Inc., a [[non-government organisation]] funded by lawyers and the [[World Bank]] and [[Commonwealth Secretariat]], dedicated to advising developing countries on establishing proper systems for democracy and justice.<ref name=autogenerated16>[https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/119692837/ ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' from Sydney, New South Wales on June 8, 1998 · Page 4<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
He was made an Officer in the [[Order of Australia]] for services to international affairs and the protection of human rights in 1998.<ref name=autogenerated11 /><ref name=autogenerated7 /> He was also the inaugural President of the [[Australian Paralympic Committee|Australian Paralympic Federation]].<ref name=autogenerated11 /><ref name=autogenerated7 /><ref name=autogenerated16 /><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=gOY71HxxIWoC&pg=PR9&lpg=PR9&dq=marcus+einfeld+paralympic&source=bl&ots=y3EMSZjdMn&sig=3HxaTg5PufMSYOjHfHm4SkNdl6U&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwintqCJuIDaAhXRm-AKHQoSDtEQ6AEIcjAP#v=onepage&q=marcus%20einfeld%20paralympic&f=false ''Protection Or Punishment?: The Detention of Asylum-seekers in Australia'' - Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Einfeld has served as an executive member of the New South Wales Jewish Board of Deputies and as a Councillor on the [[Executive Council of Australian Jewry]].<ref name=autogenerated14 /> He also started and served as the first chairman of the Australian Campaign for the Rescue of Soviet Jewry, following his earlier establishment of the London-based National Campaign for Soviet Jewry of the United Kingdom and Ireland.<ref name=autogenerated14 /> Einfeld has been a spokesperson for Israeli and Jewish causes, and has contributed to public debate on Palestine, the media, the [[United Nations]], universities, and other institutions.<ref name=autogenerated14 /> In 1997 [[President of the Palestinian National Authority]] [[Yassar Arafat]] chose him to assist in overhauling the [[Palestinian Authority]]'s legal system.<ref>[https://www.smh.com.au/news/national/full-of-opinions-yet-now-strangngely-quiet-about-himself/2006/08/11/1154803102230.html "Full of opinions, yet now strangely quiet about himself" - smh.com.au<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He was an invited speaker at [[United Israel Appeal]] (UIA) functions in Britain, the United States, Europe, Canada, and Australia.<ref name=autogenerated14 /> He is patron of the Australian Association of Jewish Holocaust Survivors and Descendants and of the [[Sydney Jewish Museum]].<ref name=autogenerated14 />
===Controversies=== In a March 2006 address on the war on terror and [[civil liberties]] at the [[University of Western Sydney]], he stated that Western powers, including Australia, had supported terrorist regimes financially, and that new [[sedition]] laws showed that Australia was "leaning towards an autocratic framework".<ref>{{cite news|title=We sponsor terror: ex-judge|last=Shiel|first=Fergus|work=[[The Age]]|date=21 March 2006 |accessdate=25 June 2007|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2006/03/20/1142703291408.html|location=Melbourne}}</ref>
Einfeld was the President of Australian Legal Resources International, a [[non-profit]] independent group of lawyers that supported [[democracy]], [[human rights]], and the [[rule of law]] in [[Developing country|developing countries]]. In August 2006, this organisation collapsed, leaving creditors, including [[AusAID]], the [[Australian Taxation Office]], and [[St.George Bank]] "thousands of dollars out of pocket."<ref>{{cite news|title=Einfeld-led company collapses in debt|last=Dick |first=Tim |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=15 August 2006|accessdate=25 June 2007|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2006/08/14/1155407741505.html}}</ref>
==Criminal conviction== {{Infobox criminal | name = Marcus Richard Einfeld | criminal_charge = {{bulleted list|[[Perjury]]|[[Perverting the course of justice]]}} | penalty = 3 years imprisonment; with a two-year non-[[parole]] period | conviction_status = Released on parole (19 March 2011) | motive = | conviction = {{bulleted list|Perjury (2008)|{{nowrap|Perverting the course of justice (2008)}}}} | comments = {{bulleted list|Revocation of commission as a [[Queen's Counsel]] (2008)|Termination as an [[Order of Australia|Officer of the Order of Australia]] (2009)}} | beginyear = | endyear = | country = | states = | locations = | apprehended = | imprisoned = | footnotes = <ref name=austlii119 /><ref name="qc revoked"/><ref name="Gazette" /><ref name=PS060821/><ref name="abc charges"/><ref name="smh trial"/><ref name=parole/> }} On 7 August 2006, Einfeld contested a {{AUD}}77 [[speeding ticket]].<ref name=autogenerated1/><ref name=autogenerated4>{{cite AustLII|NSWCCA|87|2010|litigants=Einfeld v R |date=5 May 2010 |courtname=auto}}.</ref> His car had been caught by a [[speed camera]], traveling at 60km/h in a 50km/h zone (10 km/h (6.2 mph) over the speed limit) in the Sydney suburb of [[Mosman]] on 8 January 2006.<ref name=autogenerated5>Karen Barlow (20 March 2009). [http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2008/s2522081.htm "Former Federal Court judge Marcus Einfeld sent to jail,"<!-- Bot generated title -->] ABC.</ref><ref name=autogenerated1/><ref name=autogenerated4 /> The [[BBC]] noted: "the judge was only 6 mph over the limit, which scarcely made him a [[boy racer]]."<ref name=autogenerated6 />
He contested the ticket in Downing Centre Local Court by claiming he had on that day lent his car to an old friend, Professor Teresa Brennan, who was visiting from the United States.<ref name=autogenerated11 /><ref name=autogenerated5 /><ref name=autogenerated1/> By making his claim Einfeld was avoiding a A$75 fine, and avoiding losing three of his four remaining [[demerit points]].<ref name=autogenerated5 /><ref name=autogenerated1>[https://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/books/if-only-marcus-einfeld-had-chosen-to-tell-the-truth/news-story/bc1bf3343a8514603e03649a3306126a?sv=65f18cbae0e76d6ada52d61d95745ff9 | ''The Australian''<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=autogenerated2>[https://www.smh.com.au/national/former-judge-einfeld-gets-at-least-two-years-jail--all-for-lying-about-a-77-traffic-fine-20090320-93sr.html "Former judge Einfeld gets at least two years' jail ... all for lying about a $77 traffic fine"]</ref><ref name=austlii119>{{cite AustLII|NSWSC|119|2009|litigants=R v Einfeld |courtname=auto}}.</ref> He gave evidence under oath in the Local Court, and signed a statutory declaration to that effect, and the magistrate dismissed the charge as "not proved."<ref name=autogenerated11 /> However, a junior reporter for the Sydney daily [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]'' filed a brief story which caught the attention of assistant editor Michael Beach, who discovered that Brennan had died in the United States three years before Einfeld claimed she had been driving his car, and on Beach's instruction the reporter called Einfeld to obtain his reaction.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> This was the basis for Einfeld's later conviction for knowingly making a false statement under oath.<ref name=PS060821>{{cite news|title=The Einfeld Follies: a study in ego|last=Sheehan|first=Paul|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=21 August 2006|accessdate=25 June 2007|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2006/08/20/1156012408310.html}}</ref><ref name="theage.com.au">{{cite news|title=Fare cop as judge's lies lead to prison|last=Knox|first=Malcolm|work=[[The Age]]|date=21 March 2009|accessdate=21 March 2009|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/fare-cop-as-judges-lies-lead-to-prison-20090320-94jl.html|location=Melbourne}}</ref>
When challenged by the journalist concerning Brennan's death, Einfeld claimed that he had lent his car on that day to a different Terese or Therese Brennan, who he claimed also lived in the US, and who had also died after returning to the US.<ref name=autogenerated4 /><ref name=autogenerated11 /> On 10 August 2006 a police investigation commenced into whether Einfeld had committed perjury in giving his evidence.<ref name=autogenerated4 /> On 23 August 2006, Einfeld produced a detailed 20-page statement describing the fictitious second Teresa Brennan and his supposed dealings with her.<ref name=autogenerated4 /> This was the basis for his conviction for attempting to pervert the course of justice.<ref name="theage.com.au"/>
Matters took an unusual turn when on 10 August 2006 Angela Liati, a 55-year-old Sydney woman unknown to Einfeld but who wanted to meet him, came forward and claimed that she had met Einfeld and had driven in his car with "Theahresa Brennan" (whom she had met on a meditation retreat) on a shopping expedition on the day in question.<ref>[https://www.smh.com.au/news/national/einfeld-case-liati-faces-trial/2007/12/13/1197135605002.html "Einfeld case: Liati faces trial" - smh.com.au<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=autogenerated15>https://www.smh.com.au/national/liati-found-guilty-of-perverting-justice-20090212-85kd.html</ref><ref name=autogenerated11 /> Liati said ""He has given his life to good causes and has been a brilliant judge ... a brilliant man ... and he deserves all the respect a country will give him".<ref name=autogenerated13/> Liati represented herself during an eight-day District Court jury trial and claimed that she was only endeavouring to make contact with Einfeld through her admission.<ref name=autogenerated15 /> However, she was found guilty on 12 February 2009 of perverting the course of justice and was subsequently sentenced to 200 hours' [[community service]];<ref name=autogenerated9 /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/liati-found-guilty-of-perverting-justice-20090212-85kd.html|title=Liati found guilty of perverting justice|last=Kontominas|first=Bellinda|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=12 February 2009|date=12 February 2009}}</ref> later changed to a 12-month good behaviour bond.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}}
On 29 March 2007, Einfeld was arrested by the [[New South Wales Police Force|New South Wales Police]]. He was initially charged by the [[Director of Public Prosecutions (New South Wales)]] with 13 offences, including perjury, perverting the course of justice, and making and using false statutory declarations.<ref name=autogenerated4 /><ref name="abc charges">{{cite news|title=Einfeld faces 13 charges|last=Macey|first=Jennifer| publisher=PM, [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] Radio|date=29 March 2007|accessdate=25 June 2007 |url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2007/s1885121.htm}}</ref> In theory, the charges called for a total of 154 years in jail.<ref name=autogenerated9 />
Einfeld's [[committal hearing]] was held in December 2007. The prosecution suggested the reason he lied under oath was that, had he gained the demerit points for the speeding offence, he would have been close to losing his licence. However, Einfeld denied he was aware his points were so high. One charge (hindering an investigation) was dropped. Einfeld was committed to stand trial on charges of perjury, perverting the course of justice, and traffic offences.<ref name="smh trial">{{cite news|title=Einfeld sent for trial|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=13 December 2007|accessdate=13 December 2007|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/einfeld-sent-for-trial/2007/12/13/1197135615650.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Einfeld 'lied under oath'|last=McClymont|first=Kate|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=10 December 2007|accessdate=11 December 2007 |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/einfeld-lied-under-oath/2007/12/10/1197135333854.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=First Einfeld episode features an all-female cast |last=McClymont|first=Kate|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=11 December 2007|accessdate=11 December 2007|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/first-einfeld-episode-features-an-allfemale-cast/2007/12/10/1197135376011.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Einfeld witness says memory imperfect|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=11 December 2007|accessdate=11 December 2007|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/einfeld-witness-says-memory-imperfect/2007/12/11/1197135420492.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Evidence will contradict Einfeld's story: court|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=11 December 2007|accessdate=11 December 2007|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/evidence-will-contradict-einfelds-story-court/2007/12/10/1197135349923.html}}</ref>
On 19 October 2008 the Court of Criminal Appeal dismissed another five of the charges against Einfeld, leaving only two.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/five-charges-against-einfeld-dropped/2008/10/14/1223749999081.html|title=Five charges against Einfeld dismissed|last=Jacobsen|first=Geesche|date=14 October 2008|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=14 October 2008}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated4 />
On 31 October 2008, Einfeld pleaded guilty to the two remaining charges -- to perjury, and to perverting the course of justice -- just before his trial was to commence.<ref name=autogenerated4 /> It was also revealed that he had been battling [[prostate cancer]] for several months.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24580924-601,00.html|title=Former judge Marcus Einfeld suffering prostate cancer|date=31 October 2008|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=31 October 2008}}</ref> The [[pre-sentence report]] to the court stated that Einfeld accepted responsibility for his actions.<ref name=autogenerated4 /> The head of the NSW Fraud Squad and commander of the Strike Force said its two-and-a-half year investigation investigation of the matter was "very lengthy, very protracted, very intricate".<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=autogenerated5 /> After his speeding fine case came to the attention of the Australian media, Einfeld was the subject of media reports alleging various other improprieties, including padding his curriculum vitae, purchasing doctorates from US [[diploma mill]]s, and plagiarism.<ref>{{cite news|title=Einfield quits Roosters, forced to rewrite CV |publisher=[[news.com.au]] |date=25 February 2007 |accessdate=11 December 2007 |url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,21283749-2,00.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070306030855/http://www.news.com.au/story/0%2C23599%2C21283749-2%2C00.html |archivedate=6 March 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref name=PS060821/><ref>{{cite news|title=Einfeld PhD 'is not worth the paper |last=Merritt |first=Chris |work=[[Weekend Australian]] |date=19 August 2006 |accessdate=11 December 2007 |url=http://www.saltshein.com.au/files/theaustralian_PhdNotWorththe%20Paper_August2006.pdf |format=PDF }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
On 20 March 2009, the 70-year-old retired judge Einfeld was sentenced to the maximum three years in prison for knowingly making a false statement under oath and for attempting to pervert the course of justice, with a non-[[parole]] period of two years.<ref name=autogenerated4 /> Supreme Court Justice Bruce James found Einfeld had committed "deliberate, premeditated perjury" that was "part of planned criminal activity".<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=austlii119 /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/former-judge-einfeld-gets-at-least-two-years-jail--all-for-lying-about-a-77-traffic-fine-20090320-93sr.html|title=Former judge Einfeld gets at least two years jail ... all for lying about a $77 traffic fine|last=Knox|first=Malcolm|date=20 March 2009|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=20 March 2009}}</ref> He served two years, and was released on parole on 19 March 2011.<ref name=parole>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/einfeld-released-after-two-years/story-e6frg6nf-1226024478941|title=Einfeld released after two years |work=[[The Australian]]|agency=[[Australian Associated Press|AAP]]|date=19 March 2011}}</ref>
===Reactions=== Einfeld said "I'm desperately sorry for what I did. I'm sorry to my family, my elderly mother and my children. I'm sorry to the public at large.... I lied. I can't say it any simpler than that. I told a lie, which was a disgraceful thing to do and for which I have been paying ever since."<ref name=autogenerated9 /> When Einfeld was asked if he was a dishonest man, he said: "No, I'm not dishonest, no... I don't think I'm the slightest bit dishonest. I just made a mistake."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25226258-5006784,00.html|work=The Daily Telegraph|first=Joe|last=Hildebrand|title=Marcus Einfeld breaks silence to apologise for lying|date=23 March 2009}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated9 />
On 5 November 2008, the President of the [[New South Wales Bar Association]] applied to the [[New South Wales Court of Appeal]] to withdraw Einfeld's commission as [[Queen's Counsel]], on the basis that his conduct had brought shame upon the legal profession as well as on himself.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/business/story/0,28124,24613420-36418,00.html|title=Bar moves to strip Einfeld of his QC title|last=Merritt|first=Chris|date=10 November 2008|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=10 November 2008}}</ref> On 26 November, Einfeld's commission as a Queen's Counsel was revoked.<ref name="qc revoked"/> His membership of the [[Order of Australia]] was rescinded in April 2009.<ref name="Gazette">{{cite web|url=http://gazettes.ag.gov.au/portal/govgazonline.nsf/B3CB7C0B1D916596CA2575A20025E85D/$file/S%2069.pdf |title=Order of Australia |date=24 April 2009 |work=Commonwealth of Australia Gazette |accessdate=24 April 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
[[Law Society of New South Wales|NSW Law Society]] president Joe Catanzariti said that the three-year sentence for the former judge demonstrated that "the legal profession did not protect its own", but that it was tragic to see Einfeld's reputation ruined because "the sad thing in all of this is you do have a great man who has done great works, and ... the substantive thing that started it is so trivial."<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090322110935/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/national/788779/einfeld-lied-to-avoid-demerit-judge "Marcus Einfeld jailed for perjury,"<!-- Bot generated title -->] 20 March 2009.</ref> Reacting to a call to strip Einfeld of his pension, [[Chief Justice of New South Wales]] [[Jim Spigelman]] wrote in an April 2009 letter to NSW Attorney General [[John Hatzistergos]] that pensions should be safe when judges were already retired, they were a deferred part of their salary, criminal law was sufficient punishment, and that it would be even more unusual if the offence "bears no relationship" to the judge's former duties.<ref name=autogenerated13>[https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/abc-boss-in-support-of-einfeld/news-story/7f60ad2601c19eb2ebc82ede51e8d6d5?sv=55d13e7087b8663fc3bda7c3ef0344f3 "We’re for Sydney,"<!-- Bot generated title -->] ''Daily Telegraph''.</ref> Spigelman continued that then-federal Attorney General [[Robert McClelland (Australian politician)|Robert McClelland]] and state attorneys-general should "impose a cooling off period on themselves" for reacting to vehement short-term ad hoc media campaigns."<ref name=autogenerated13 />
Sydney barrister and author [[Charles Waterstreet]] observed: "at the time ... Einfeld wrote a false name for the driver ... at the heart of the sorry case ... the maximum, I repeat, the maximum fine for making a false declaration of that nature was $1,000."<ref>[https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/the-mob-shows-no-mercy-20141112-9ew3.html "The mob shows no mercy,"] ''The Sydney Herald''.</ref> Former Australian Minister for [[Minister for Home Affairs (Australia)|Home Affairs]], [[Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts (Australia)|the Environment]], and [[Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts (Australia)|Arts]] [[Barry Cohen]] noted that: <blockquote>"many journalists ... feel it is beholden upon them to mention that a person is Jewish, particularly if they have been naughty... He received three years in custody... By comparison ... a young lady living in Canberra got four years for killing her boyfriend. Shortly after Marcus Einfeld was sentenced, Stephen Linnell, one of the top advisers to Victoria police commissioner [[Christine Nixon]], pleaded guilty to three counts of perjury and disclosing confidential information of the [[Office of Police Integrity]]. He received an eight-month [[suspended sentence]] and a $5,000 fine. The glaring difference between these crimes and the punishments incurred is extraordinary."<ref>[https://www.spectator.co.uk/2009/04/guilty-yes-but-entitled-to-some-respect/ "Guilty, yes, but entitled to some respect,"<!-- Bot generated title -->] ''The Spectator''.</ref></blockquote>
===Removal from the roll=== On 23 July 2009, the New South Wales Court of Appeal ordered that Einfeld's name be removed from the roll of lawyers.<ref name=austlii255>{{cite AustLII|NSWCA|255|2009|litigants=Council of the New South Wales Bar Association v Einfeld |courtname=auto}}.</ref> On 28 August 2009, the Court of Appeal delivered its reasons for making those declarations and orders,<ref name=austlii255 /> finding proven allegations that, in addition to the 2006 statutory declaration in respect of which he had been convicted, Einfeld had also sworn a series of statutory declarations in 1999, 2003, and 2004 falsely nominating other persons as the drivers of his car who he knew had not been driving the car so as to avoid traffic infringements.<ref>Paragraphs 19 to 56 of the judgment</ref> Einfeld agreed not to apply for re-admission.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/jailbird-judge-marcus-einfeld-struck-off-20090723-due1.html|title=Jailbird judge Marcus Einfeld struck off|last=Alexander|first=Harriet|date=23 July 2009|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=23 July 2009}}</ref> The court also considered the circumstances in which Einfeld had produced the 20-page statement describing the fictitious Teresa Brennan, and found that:<ref>Paragraph 70 of the judgment</ref>
<blockquote>This statement reflects a studied, careful and premeditated attempt through a series of direct lies to influence the outcome of the administration of justice. It involves not a passing mistake, not an unfortunate and apparently uncharacteristic lapse but a studied and deliberate attempt to avoid the consequences of his actions and to deflect and pervert the course of justice. It may well be that the course of justice was in relation to a minor matter, standing alone. That, however, is not the point... All these facts ... when taken as a whole reflect deeply on the character of the defendant. Some of his falsehoods were committed at a time when he held high judicial office in the administration of justice in this country. Some were committed when he held the position as a practitioner... These matters, having taken place over a period of some seven years ... reveal a clear unfitness to remain on the Roll of Local Lawyers.</blockquote>
==Later life== In 2011, Einfeld was devoting his time to community works, including working on Australian [[prison reform]].<ref name=autogenerated1 />

The '''Ministry of Justice of Cameroon''' is the Department responsible for administering the Cameroon justice system. As of May 2004, the Minister of State for Justice was [[Amadou Ali]]. The legal system in the Cameroon is complex with a constitution developed in 1972 and revised in 1996 as well as elements of the [[Code Napoleon]], [[Common Law]] and [[customary law]]. In early 2005, the Ministry of Justice became responsible for administering the prison system due to unrest in the prisons. The Ministry of Justice also has a shared responsibility for administering [[human rights]] in the Cameroon. There have been serious allegations about use of torture by police and military officials in the Cameroon.
==Administration of justice== The constitution of the Cameroon provides that the [[Supreme Court of the Cameroon]] is the highest court existing in the country. In addition, the country has appeal courts, circuit courts and magistrates courts. The Supreme Court is located in [[Yaoundé]] as is the [[Cameroon High Court of Justice]] consisting of nine titular judges and six surrogate judges. The other courts are located throughout the country.
The constitution provides for a Constitutional Council responsible for constitutional law but this body has not yet been established. In lieu of this Council, the Supreme Court carries out its duty. Cameroon claims that the judiciary is independent from the executive and the legislature. However, the US State Department claims that the judiciary is subordinate to the Ministry of Justice and that the Supreme Court can only consider a constitutional matter when referred to it by the [[President of Cameroon]]. The Supreme Court is responsible for adjudicating disputes between the president and the National Assembly.
The President of the Cameroon is responsible for appointing judges and also has the power to dismiss them. The [[Higher Judicial Council of Cameroon]] advises him on the nomination of judges and magistrates and has responsibility for judicial discipline.
The [[Parliamentary Court of Justice]] is responsible for judging acts by the President in cases where he or she has been accused of high treason. This Court also has responsibility for judging acts by the [[Prime Minister of the Cameroon]], other members of the Government and other senior officials in cases relevant to state security.
==Legal traditions== Prior to independence, jurisdiction over Cameroon was shared between the United Kingdom and France under a [[League of Nations]] mandate issued in 1919. The northern part of the British area became part of Nigeria while the Christian southern part joined with the French area. As a consequence, the country inherited a dual legal system including parts of the Code Napoleon and the common law. However, on 12 July 2005 the National Assembly (Assemblé Nationale) approved a law to harmonize the country's criminal procedure code.
In addition, traditional courts still play a significant role in domestic, property and probate. The court system honours tribal laws and customs when these do not conflict with national laws.
==Prison system== The Ministry of Justice became responsible for administering the prison system at the beginning of 2005 taking over responsibility from the [[Ministry of Territorial Administration of Cameroon]]. This follows disturbances caused by overcrowding of prisons and long stays in detention without charges of prisons.
There were 15,903 people in the prison system as of 1997 representing 115 per 100,000 population. However, the population of the prisons has grown rapidly in recent years. The New Bell prison in [[Douala]] was meant to hold 800 inmates but holds 3,100. The [[International Centre for Prison Studies]] estimates that Cameroon has the second highest occupancy rate in the world after Barbados with approximately half awaiting trial.
The Government has built two new prisons but has not provided enough staff resulting in the establishment of "anti-gangs" of inmates to preserve order.
==Human rights== The preamble of the constitution adopted in 1996 incorporates parts of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] and the [[African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights]]. The Ministry of Justice shares responsibility for administering human rights with the Ministry of Territorial Administration.
A person who considers that their rights may have been violated may take their case either to the statutory courts or to the traditional courts. They may also petition the [[National Committee on Human Rights and Freedoms]] established in 1990. They may also seek compensation through the courts. If a person is acquitted, discharged or has been wrongfully held in custody, they are not entitled to compensation unless they can prove that the judge was wrong or the system did not function properly.
The [[United Nations Commission on Human Rights]] held hearings in 2003 into allegations of torture by the police and the military. The major area of concern was the prison network although it has been acknowledged that Cameroon had made some progress in improving its human rights performance.

'''The Miscarriage of Justice Organization''' (MOJO) is a charity dedicated to human rights and to changing the criminal justice system in order to reduce the number of [[miscarriage]]s of [[criminal justice]] and increase the level of professional after-care for victims.
After his conviction was overturned and his incarceration ended, Patrick Hill, one of the so-called [[Birmingham Six]], set out to assist people who claim to have been wrongfully convicted. The Miscarriage of Justice Organisation is a voluntary sector non profit making organisation and a registered charity.
==External links== * [http://www.miscarriagesofjustice.org MOJO official site]

[[File:NAAQS Non Attainment Counties 09302017.svg|thumb|US counties that are designated "nonattainment" for the Clean Air Act's NAAQS. Valid 9/30/2017.]]The U.S. '''National Ambient Air Quality Standards''' ('''NAAQS''', pronounced \'naks\) are standards for harmful pollutants<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://ohioepa.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/907/~/definition-of-national-ambient-air-quality-standards-(naaqs)|title=Definition of National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS)|website=ohioepa.custhelp.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref>. Established by the [[United States]] [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) under authority of the [[Clean Air Act (United States)|Clean Air Act]] (42 U.S.C. 7401 et seq.), NAAQS is applied for outdoor air throughout the country.<ref name=":0">[http://tapseis.anl.gov/glossacro/dsp_wordpopup.cfm?word_id=444 Trans-Alaska Pipeline System Renewal Environmental Impact Statement article]</ref>
==Standards== The standards are listed in {{USCFR|40|50}}. Primary standards are designed to protect human health<ref>“Early Implementation of the Clean Air Act of 1970 in California.” EPA Alumni Association. [http://www.epaalumni.org/history/video/interview.cfm?id=38 Video], [https://www.epaalumni.org/userdata/pdf/2B9E3C6816EC9466.pdf#page=4 Transcript] (see p4). July 12, 2016.</ref>, with an adequate margin of safety, including sensitive populations such as children, the elderly, and individuals suffering from respiratory diseases. Secondary standards are designed to protect public welfare (including effects on soils, water, crops, vegetation, man-made materials, animals, wildlife, weather, visibility, and climate), damage to property, transportation hazards, economic values, and personal comfort and well-being from any known or anticipated adverse effects of a pollutant. A district meeting a given standard is known as an "attainment area" for that standard, and otherwise a "non-attainment area".<ref name=":0" />
EPA set NAAQS for six major pollutants listed as below. These six pollutants are also the criteria pollutants.<ref name=":1" />
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Pollutant !! Type !! Standard!! Averaging Time!! Form{{ref|a|a}} !! Regulatory Citation |- | rowspan="2" | [[Sulfur dioxide]] (SO<sub>2</sub>) | Primary | 75 ppb | 1-hour | 99th Percentile of 1-hour daily maximum concentrations, averaged over 3 years | {{USCFR|40|50|17|a}} |- | Secondary | 0.5 ppm (1,300 μg/m³) | 3-hour | Not to be exceeded more than once per year | {{USCFR|40|50|5|a}} |- | [[Particulate matter#Health effects|Particulate matter]] (PM<sub>10</sub>) | Primary and Secondary | 150 μg/m³ | 24-hour | Not to be exceeded more than once per year on average over 3 years | {{USCFR|40|50|6|a}} |- | rowspan="3" | Fine particulate matter (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) | Primary | 12 μg/m³ | annual | Annual mean, averaged over 3 years | {{USCFR|40|50|18|a}} |- | Secondary | 15 μg/m³ | annual | Annual mean, averaged over 3 years | {{USCFR|40|50|7|a}} |- | Primary and Secondary | 35 μg/m³ | 24-hour | 98th percentile, averaged over 3 years | {{USCFR|40|50|18|a}} |- | rowspan="2" | [[Carbon monoxide]] (CO) | Primary | 35 ppm (40 [[Milligram|mg]]/m³) | 1-hour |Not to be exceeded more than once per year | {{USCFR|40|50|8|a(2)}} |- | Primary | 9 ppm (10 mg/m³) | 8-hour | Not to be exceeded more than once per year | {{USCFR|40|50|8|a(1)}} |- | rowspan="2" | [[Ozone]] (O<sub>3</sub>) | Primary and Secondary | 0.12 ppm (235 μg/m³) | 1-hour{{ref|b|b}} | expected number of days per calendar year, with maximum hourly average concentration greater than 0.12 ppm, is equal to or less than 1 | {{USCFR|40|50|9|a}} |- | Primary and Secondary | 0.070 ppm (140 μg/m³) | 8-hour | Annual fourth-highest daily maximum 8-hour concentration, averaged over 3 years | {{USCFR|40|50|19|a}} |- | [[Nitrogen dioxide]] (NO<sub>2</sub>) | Primary and Secondary | 0.053 ppm (100 μg/m³) | annual | Annual mean | {{USCFR|40|50|11|ab}} |- | [[Lead]] (Pb) | Primary and Secondary | 0.15 μg/m³ | Rolling 3 months | Not to be exceeded | {{USCFR|40|50|12|a}} |}
*{{note|a|a}}Each standard has its own criteria for how many times it may be exceeded *{{note|b|b}}As of June 15, 2005, the 1-hour ozone standard no longer applies to areas designated with respect to the 8-hour ozone standard (which includes most of the United States, except for portions of 10 states). *Source: [https://www.epa.gov/criteria-air-pollutants/naaqs-table USEPA]
== Detection methods == The EPA [[National Exposure Research Laboratory]] can designate a measurement device using an established technological basis as a '''Federal Reference Method''' (FRM) to certify that the device has undergone a testing and analysis protocol, and can be used to monitor NAAQS compliance. Devices based on new technologies can be designated as a '''Federal Equivalent Method''' (FEM).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hall|first=Eric S.|last2=Kaushik|first2=Surender M.|last3=Vanderpool|first3=Robert W.|last4=Duvall|first4=Rachelle M.|last5=Beaver|first5=Melinda R.|last6=Long|first6=Russell W.|last7=Solomon|first7=Paul A.|last8=Hall|first8=Eric S.|last9=Kaushik|first9=Surender M.|date=2014|title=Integrating Sensor Monitoring Technology into the Current Air Pollution Regulatory Support Paradigm: Practical Considerations|url=http://article.sapub.org/10.5923.j.ajee.20140406.02.html|journal=American Journal of Environmental Engineering|language=en|volume=4|issue=6|pages=|doi=10.5923/j.ajee.20140406.02|issn=2166-465X|via=|doi-broken-date=2018-09-22}}</ref> FEMs are based on different sampling and/or analyzing technologies than FRMs, but are required to provide the same decision making quality when making NAAQS attainment determinations. Approved new methods are formally announced through publication in the [[Federal Register]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/air-research/epa-scientists-develop-federal-reference-equivalent-methods-measuring-key-air|title=EPA scientists develop Federal Reference & Equivalent Methods for measuring key air pollutants|last=|first=|date=2016-12-29|website=U.S. Environmental Protection Agency|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-28}}</ref> A complete list of FRMs and FEMs is available.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cfpub.epa.gov/si/si_public_record_report.cfm?dirEntryId=321491|title=Reference and Equivalent Methods Used to Measure National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) Criteria Air Pollutants - Volume I|last=Gilliam|first=Joseph H.|last2=Hall|first2=Eric S.|date=2016-07-13|website=U.S. [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]]|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-28}}</ref>
==Air quality control region== An air quality control region is an area, designated by the federal government, where communities share a common air pollution problem. <ref>{{cite web|title=EPA document|url=http://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyNET.exe/P10053PA.TXT?ZyActionD=ZyDocument&Client=EPA&Index=Prior+to+1976&Docs=&Query=AP102%20or%20f&Time=&EndTime=&SearchMethod=1&TocRestrict=n&Toc=&TocEntry=&QField=pubnumber^%22AP102%22&QFieldYear=&QFieldMonth=&QFieldDay=&UseQField=pubnumber&IntQFieldOp=1&ExtQFieldOp=1&XmlQuery=&File=D:\zyfiles\Index%20Data\70thru75\Txt\00000006\P10053PA.txt&User=ANONYMOUS&Password=anonymous&SortMethod=h%7C-&MaximumDocuments=10&FuzzyDegree=0&ImageQuality=r75g8/r75g8/x150y150g16/i425&Display=p%7Cf&DefSeekPage=x&SearchBack=ZyActionL&Back=ZyActionS&BackDesc=Results%20page&MaximumPages=1&ZyEntry=1&SeekPage=x&ZyPURL}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Air pollution]] * [[Air Quality Index]] * [[Asthma]] * [[Atmospheric dispersion modeling]] * [[Clean Air Act (1990)]] * [[Portable Emissions Measurement System]] * [[Toxic Substances Control Act of 1976]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.epa.gov/ttn/naaqs/ EPA summary of the National Ambient Air Quality Standards] * [http://www.epa.gov/air/criteria.html EPA summary for Air & Radiation] * [http://www.epa.gov/oar/oaqps/greenbk/ EPA Green Book] showing non-attainment, maintenance, and attainment areas * [http://lungaction.org/reports/sota05_cities.html Most Polluted Cities, 2005] – American Lung Association *[http://www.epaalumni.org/history/video/interview.cfm?id=38 EPA Alumni Association Oral History Video "Early Implementation of the Clean Air Act of 1970 in California.”]

{{Orphan|date=August 2016}}
'''PEC 215''' is a [[bill (law)|proposed]] [[constitutional amendment]] to the [[constitution of Brazil]].
It intends to delegate exclusively to Congress the duty of demarcation of [[indigenous peoples|indigenous]] and [[Quilombola]] territories, as well as the ratification of land already approved.<ref name="therealnews">{{cite web|url=http://therealnews.com/t2/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=31&Itemid=74&jumival=10867|title=Brazil Agrobusiness Lobby Set to Appropriate Native Land and Timber|publisher=therealnews.com|accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref> <ref name="ebc">{{cite web|url=http://radios.ebc.com.br/brasil-rural/edicao/2015-10/deputado-diz-que-aprovacao-da-pec-215-nao-aumenta-violencia-contra|title=Deputado diz que aprovação da PEC 215 não vai aumentar violência contra indígena|publisher=radios.ebc.com.br|accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref> It would prohibit the expansion of already existing indigenous areas.<ref name="noticiasagricolas">{{cite web|url=http://www.noticiasagricolas.com.br/noticias/questoes-indigenas/164109-pec-215-nota-oficial-da-presidencia-da-republica-desaprova-medida.html#.VyCqPVJefId|title=PEC 215: conheça a posição do Governo e o que pensa a Agricultura - Notícias Agrícolas|publisher=noticiasagricolas.com.br|accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref> One of the proposal sections provides compensation of the Union to farmers who have properties absorbed by areas demarcated as indigenous land.<ref name="noticiasagricolas2">{{cite web|url=http://www.noticiasagricolas.com.br/noticias/questoes-indigenas/163982-comissao-aprova-tirar-do-executivo-poder-para-demarcar-terra-indigena.html#.VyCq6FJefIc|title=PEC 215: Comissão da Câmara aprova proposta que transfere decisão sobre... - Notícias Agrícolas|publisher=noticiasagricolas.com.br|accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref> The Federal Constitution considers that indigenous lands belong to the Union and, therefore, there is no compensation to those who lose the ownership of the territory when the demarcation is recognized.<ref name="noticiasagricolas2"/>
Currently, the government and Funai are responsible for demarcation.<ref name="brasilienportal">{{cite web|url=http://www.brasilienportal.ch/news/indio-news/61536-kommission-spricht-sich-fuer-demarkation-von-indio-territorien-durch-kongress-aus/|title=Kommission spricht sich für Demarkation von Indio-Territorien durch Kongress aus » BrasilienPortal|publisher=brasilienportal.ch|accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref> In the future, indigenous people might only be able to claim an area, they have lived in and used by 1988. <ref name="brasilienportal"/> It would give Congress the final say on new demarcations, a fact that displeases the indigenous leaders because of the strength of lobbyists.<ref name="noticiasagricolas2"/> Much of the protected area of [[Indigenous territory (Brazil)|indigenous territories]] are [[rain forest]]s being important for [[water]] and [[climate]]. There are farmers, who have filed an appeal.<ref name="noticiasagricolas2"/> PEC 215 has been approved by a parliamentary committee.<ref name="noticiasagricolas2"/> The proposal is being processed for 15 years in parliament.<ref name="noticiasagricolas2"/> Members of the [[Chamber of Deputies (Brazil)|Chamber of Deputies]] of [[Workers' Party (Brazil)|PT]], [[Communist Party of Brazil|PCdoB]], [[Green Party (Brazil)|PV]], [[Socialism and Liberty Party|PSOL]] and [[Sustainability Network|REDE]] were against the bill.<ref name="noticiasagricolas2"/>
Approval of the bill depends on two rounds of voting in the plenary sessions of the Chamber of Deputies and the [[Federal Senate]], with qualified quorum, that is, with the votes of at least 308 deputies and 49 senators.<ref name="noticiasagricolas2"/> Parliamentarians opposed to the bill have said they will question its constitutionality in the Supreme Court.<ref name="noticiasagricolas2"/> The bill needs three fifths of the votes in senate to be approved.<ref name="cartacapital">{{cite web|url=http://www.cartacapital.com.br/sociedade/senadores-aderem-a-manifesto-contra-a-pec-215-7012.html|title=Uma esperança para as terras indígenas? — CartaCapital|publisher=cartacapital.com.br|accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref> Great land owners have a great impact in congress.<ref name="brasilienportal"/> Protests by indigenous people prevented a vote on PEC 215 in 2014.<ref name="brasilienportal2">{{cite web|url=http://www.brasilienportal.ch/news/indio-news/56065-proteste-der-indios-verhindern-diskussion-und-abstimmung-zur-pec-215/|title=Proteste der Indios verhindern Diskussion und Abstimmung zur PEC 215 » BrasilienPortal|publisher=brasilienportal.ch|accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref> <ref name="ebc2">{{cite web|url=http://radios.ebc.com.br/jornal-da-amazonia-2a-edicao/edicao/2015-11/indigenas-vao-camara-protestar-contra-pec-215|title=Indígenas vão à Câmara protestar contra a PEC 215|publisher=radios.ebc.com.br|accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref> Indigenous people have protested against the bill in front of the Chamber of Deputies. <ref name="ebc2"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
